Vine por el llamativo pixel art y me quedé por la exquisita narrativa (y un poco por ese sonido acaricia tímpanos).  

Cómo el espacio, y compartirlo, te oprime o te libera.
Hasta qué punto los objetos que nos rodean, que poseemos o a los que nos apegamos nos aportan identidad, sentimiento de pertenencia, nos ayudan a avanzar o a quedar estancados.  
Cómo unas meras instantáneas de las diferentes mudanzas que acomete nuestro personaje protagonista pueden contar una historia a ese nivel de profundidad.

Si eres millenial te va a gustar el doble que si no lo eres, aunque puede que lo disfrutes igualmente.
Si tienes TOC vas a estar un poco j-o-d-i-d-o, pero la frustración es una mecánica en este juego. 
Si eres detallista, observador o te gusta profundizar serás capaz de ver decenas de detalles que para otros pasarán desapercibidos (aparte de los obvios). 

Es caro para lo que ofrece, pero lo que ofrece es de altísima calidad. 

En definitiva, si estás aquí, espero que sea porque te llamó la atención lo que dije al principio y/o cumples algo de lo antes mencionado, porque entonces vas a vivir una experiencia para guardar en la caja de mudanzas de tu recuerdo.

150560012.review:
[h1][b]ANÁLISIS DE [i]UNPACKING[/i]:[/b][/H1]

La inmensa mayoría de personas hemos vivido a lo largo de nuestra vida una o varias mudanzas. Ya sea porque por el trabajo de nuestros padres hemos tenido que abandonar el hogar donde nacimos y crecimos, por un divorcio, por problemas económicos; por mejorar nuestra situación y poder vivir en un lugar mejor; por independizarnos; por irnos a vivir con nuestra pareja; por comprar una casa más grande porque vamos a ser padres...

Las mudanzas siempre suponen un momento importante en nuestras vidas, ya sea por un buen motivo o por una mala experiencia. No consiste solo en mover nuestras cosas de un lugar a otro, se trata de un nuevo comienzo en otro lugar, acompañados de los bienes materiales más útiles y a los que más aprecio les tenemos, dejando atrás los demás.

Es precisamente de esto de lo que trata Unpacking. Tendremos como objetivo desempaquetar todas las cajas de las mudanzas que vamos a realizar a lo largo de nuestra vida. Con esta sencilla pero original misión, nos cuenta una bonita historia a lo largo de los años. A continuación, os cuento con más detalle.

[h1]Argumento:[/h1] (no contiene spoilers)

En Unpacking no se nos narra una historia de la forma convencional. En su lugar, la tendremos que ir descubriendo e imaginándola mediante los objetos que vamos viendo. Por ejemplo, podremos descubrir el sexo de nuestro personaje viendo el tipo de ropa que usa, la etapa de vida en la que se encuentra, las cosas a las que le tiene más aprecio porque las ha conservado con el paso de los años, las que ha dejado atrás conforme ha ido madurando, sus gustos y aficiones... esta original fórmula de contarnos la historia y de hacer que nos sintamos identificados en etapas de nuestra vida al ver los escenarios y los diferentes objetos. Esto hará que surja la nostalgia, siendo sin duda el punto fuerte de Unpacking.

[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1]

El manejo es muy ameno y sencillo. Todo se maneja con el ratón (también se puede usar mando, aunque no lo he probado aún). Simplemente hacemos clic sobre las cajas y se abrirán, y de cada una de ellas tendremos que ir sacando los objetos que hay que colocar en cada una de las estancias que se nos muestren. Cada nivel representa un año, una etapa de nuestra vida. Desde nuestra niñez hasta la madurez, viendo pasar una vida y su evolución por delante de nuestros ojos. 

Al final se trata de un juego de bloques en el que podemos "decorar" la casa, pero solo hasta cierto punto porque a la hora de pasarnos los niveles tendremos que colocar los objetos en lugares donde tengan sentido. Este es uno de los problemas que le veo al juego, y es que aunque coloquemos las cosas en sitios donde podrían ir perfectamente, el juego las detecta como erróneas, teniendo que buscar otro lugar que considere correcto. Una vez lo finalicemos si podremos colocar las cosas a nuestro antojo. 

El juego puede parecer que es solo para relajarse, pero en ocasiones ese supuesto relax puede convertirse en agobio al ver que hay muy poco espacio y muchos objetos por colocar, quedando todo el escenario excesivamente sobrecargado en ocasiones y pudiendo generar estrés en el jugador (como ha sido mi caso, que a veces soy algo maniático con el orden de ciertas cosas e igualmente desordenado para otras xD)

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]

Unpacking tiene gráficos 2D de estilo pixel art con vista isométrica, con unos diseños muy simpáticos y agradables. Escenarios detallados que fácilmente podrían recordarnos a habitaciones y lugares en los que hemos vivido. Podemos girar los objetos para verlos y colocarlos de la forma que nosotros queramos, pero los escenarios son estáticos. De haberse podido ver desde distintos ángulos habría sido mejor, aunque no es algo que se eche especialmente en falta. 

[h1]Sonido:[/h1]

La banda sonora corre a cargo de Jeff van Dyck, con melodías muy agradables y amenas que sonarán de fondo mientas desempacamos, pudiendo cambiarlas por las que suenan en las radios disponibles en los niveles. El problema de este apartado es que hay tramos en los que la música acaba y se queda un largo silencio hasta que comienza de nuevo, a no ser que vayamos a posta a encender antes una radio. Esto me ha parecido un error de bulto, porque aunque los sonidos al abrir las cajas, mover y colocar los objetos están muy conseguidos, además de tener mucha variedad, el silencio de fondo se siente extraño hasta que comienza de nuevo la melodía, que es en gran parte la "culpable" de que jugar Unpacking sea una experiencia que puede llegar a ser emotiva. 

Tenéis la banda sonora completa de Unpacking disponible en el siguiente enlace de Spotify:  [url=https://open.spotify.com/intl-es/album/546P1fkMWTbVjeCMivORqf?si=5RqoNSrxQ_WsoEFqJFQrPg]Banda sonora de Unpacking[/url]

Mi lista de pros y contras a modo de resumen:

[H1][b]PROS:[/b][/H1]

- La estética Pixel Art

- La original forma de contarnos la historia

- Ideal para la gente a la que le gusta tener todo ordenado hasta el extremo

- La banda sonora es muy buena

- Puede llegar a ser un juego muy nostálgico

- Es muy entretenido y ameno

- Tiene logros Steam

- Tiene cromos y artículos en la tienda de puntos de Steam

- Tiene guardado de la partida en la nube Steam Cloud

- Se puede conseguir bastante barato en páginas de claves

[H1][b]CONTRAS:[/b][/H1]

- Algunos objetos no se reconocen demasiado bien, poniéndonos más complicado saber donde ubicarlos

- Se puede hacer repetitivo demasiado pronto

- Hay muchos momentos en los que no hay música de fondo, tarda demasiado en arrancar de nuevo

- Aunque puede parecer un juego para relajarse, en mi opinión a veces es estresante y agobiante ver todos los escenarios tan sobrecargados de objetos y sin demasiado espacio donde colocarlos

- Su precio me parece elevado para lo que ofrece, especialmente por su corta duración, solo recomendaría su compra de oferta muy rebajado o en alguna página de keys baratas

[H1]Conclusión:[/h1]
------------------------

Un juego precioso a nivel audiovisual y con un planteamiento muy original. Muy recomendable si te llama la atención la propuesta, eso sí, recomiendo comprarlo solo de oferta ya que su precio habitual me parece elevado para lo que ofrece dada su corta duración.

Si mi análisis te ha gustado o te ha servido de ayuda, agradecería que dejaras un voto positivo para que pueda llegar a más gente. También se agradecen los premios. ¡Gracias por leerme! No dudéis en dejar vuestros comentarios o dudas, responderé lo antes posible.

150468900.review:
[h1][url=store.steampowered.com/app/1135690/Unpacking/]Unpacking[/url] follows a young girl's emancipation into adulthood with the unusual delight of discovering the next item in a box and where to best place it.[/h1]

It is a cute concept that wins in simplicity, delivery and creativity. Sorting items after moving into a new home may technically sound like a boring chore to some but it turned out to be a very enjoyable experience, given the proper laid-back state of mind.

Appreciate subtleties like how your character will not touch her roommate's stuff but she can later easily reorganize her lover's, or how you can place your toothbrush in a cup by the sink. Figure out where mismatched items go, in which room or specific location. Stack things neatly and make your place comfortable and tidy.

Scenes increase in complexity, with new and more rooms available as your character matures through her life stages, gets into new studies, goes through breakups or new relationships, and achieves professional success. Each scene marks a key change in her life. It surprisingly achieves a decent form of minimal storytelling without words or on-screen characters.

I appreciate short, candid experiences but Unpacking still ends rather abruptly. I was genuinely expecting the main character to grow into old age, maybe even end on a bittersweet note, but the developers chose to leave the story in her prime years instead, which gives it a bit of unfinished state.

You can organize items anywhere that makes sense, and while the game is relatively permissive it won't let you leave irregular arrangements untended. Aside from placing things in a temporary location while you figure out where you really want them, there isn't much of a puzzle component.

Without any description of what an item is, few ones were a little more difficult to figure out, but most are easily identified. Anyone who's ever run a household will instinctively know where most things go. There is rarely an occasion where you will run out of place, though a few rooms are more cramped than others. Furniture can't be moved, so the basics of the room have to remain untouched.

Earn stickers for placing special combinations of items together. Take photos of your rooms for the scrapbook.

The game is built on okay pixels but it is not visually outstanding. The pastel art style did not really appeal to me as it felt more functional than inventive, but it also does not detract my appreciation. The soundtrack felt likewise serviceable but relatively bland, despite good sound effects. I was drawn to the game's content and freshness more than its presentation style.

[h3]Positive[/h3]
[list]
[*] Simple and creative concept
[*] A charming and relaxing experience, almost cathartic
[*] Everything in its right place, leave no mess behind
[*] Items stack neatly where appropriate
[*] Stickers earned from special item combinations
[*] Scenes tell a story from key moments in the character's life without words
[/list]

[h3]Negative[/h3]
[list]
[*] Ends rather abruptly
[*] Okay pixels, not visually outstanding
[*] Serviceable but bland soundtrack
[*] No item descriptions
[/list]

150410459.review:
A game that is about taking things out of boxes and arranging them in rooms, which is the disguise of a story that is about the life of a person told through their possessions. Not only do the items themselves tell you about their journey through life, but the ways in which the environments are arranged - and more importantly, how they allow you to arrange your items in them - tell you a lot about how the person we're following fits in. The items you unpack and their relation to the space they have to fit into is used to subtle and great effect.

[spoiler]Without a doubt the most powerful example of this used in the game is the episode moving in with a boyfriend: the way everything's arranged means you have to move a LOT of stuff just to fit in making it feel like you're moving into a space that doesn't really want you there, but the most painful part by far is that your framed college degree, which usually takes pride of place on the wall, has to go UNDER THE BED as though it simply doesn't exist. Brutal.[/spoiler]

The artstyle is pretty cozy and is generally readable, although I did have trouble figuring out what one or two items were (which is important, because sometimes you'll get items that aren't meant for the room their box is in). The game does sometimes have seemingly illogical item placement rules, but you can turn them off in the options if it bothers you too much; I would recommend NOT turning them off for your first playthrough tho, just to get the intended experience which is important to the story.

Overall, a very comfy experience that allowed me to indulge my OCD tendencies wonderfully. No, seriously, it's absolutely vital that all the books of a certain thickness are arranged on that exact shelf in a specific order from tallest to shortest and I will brook NO arguments to the contrary.

A lovely wee short game with some beautiful, soft, environmental storytelling. I felt myself smiling as I unpacked things I recognised from previous moves as if they were indeed my own possessions. I adored the way that the character grew, how their rooms, needs, space, and style developed but also the little knick-knacks and books and games along the way that stayed with them and showcased that they hand't outgrown their hobbies and interests. 

I very much adored the nostalgia factor as a child of the 90s and appreciated the pixelated nods to various known franchises. The graphics style is cute, clean, and pleasant. 150337364.review:
---REVIEW ON "Unpacking"---

=Overview=
In the few short hours that I have played this game (spread out over two days), I was taken on a sentimental journey. This game tackled things that I myself have had to go through -- as well as things I hope to achieve: 
sentimentality, family, the concept of "home", and how material items can affect our perceptions of what makes a home.

=WHAT I LIKED=
- The Music: The music was cozy and emotional, reminiscent of composers like Lena Raine and C418.
- The Art Style: The art style helped to cement the cozy feel of the game. In a strange way, it reminded me of Point-and-Click mystery games from the days of Flash.
- The Story: The story, even being unspoken, hit very close to home for me particularly (This may have been influenced by the fact I used my real name for the name of the first album).

=WHAT I DISLIKED=
All in all, there was very little I disliked. Any technical issues I encountered could be attributed to my potato-tier computer. However, there were some items I had trouble recognising until (and even still I'm not sure they were what I thought they were). 

=THINGS I WOULD LIKED TO HAVE SEEN=
Personally, I would liked to have seen a sort of sandbox mode in the game. However, this only comes from my desire to have a home that doesn't look like it should be condemned.

=CONCLUSION=
Normally, games like this tend to make me stress out. But I found this stress to be missing while I played! I found myself actively interpreting the story in a way I haven't since I played "Celeste" and I was humming along to the music as I tried to figure out where to stuff a DS. Overall, "Unpacking" is a phenomenal game and a wonderful experience for those who enjoy organisation, interior design, and nostalgia. 




!!!\\\WARNING: EVERYTHING PAST THIS POINT MAY INCLUDE SPOILERS///!!!


=EXTRA COMMENTS=
Throughout the game, I had this lingering feeling that the main character would turn out to be lesbian. I was pleased to see I was right! This really only made the story resonate with me further, given my own preferences away from the screen. I found the ending incredibly sweet and wholly deserved.

Not so much really a game as a time waster.  

There's not really a story, more so signs of a story.  

The game start with you in an apartment with multiple rooms and boxes of "stuff" to unpack and put where the developer feels those items should be.  That's it.   Its kinda like a reverse hidden item game.  If this is fun for you then please, come clean my house.  

As for story, each "level" is another apartment which I guess is supposed to be the person's next apartment and the items you unpack are supposed to signify changes in their lives.  Real deep.  

The frustrating thing about this is unpacking something and having no idea what it's supposed to be.  Is this a book?  a DVD? a video game?  Who knows.  So you have to randomly try putting in everywhere until you luck upon the place it was meant to be. 

 It this fun?  Is this supposed to be game play?  Not for me, for me it's annoying and frustrating.    

I picked this up on sale because it had good reviews.  I'd be annoyed if I paid full price for it.

unpacking is what it says on the box, a game about unpacking boxes, moving-your-home boxes that is. You come to new living spaces which have furniture and varying degrees of decorations. 150266271.review: I personally would recommend waiting for a sale, as there is only 3-5 hours of gameplay depending on how methodical you are. Price tag aside though, this game is beautifully simple and the environmental storytelling is both heartwarming and heartbreaking. A few of my favorite moments were [spoiler](1) when the protag is moving in to their boyfriend's cluttered apartment and the only place to put their diploma is under the bed, (2) the next chapter, where we move back into our childhood bedroom and keep the photo of said boyfriend, but the only place you're allowed to put it is hidden away in a cabinet, and (3) the box in the last chapter that's just chock full of the same book over and over again. At first I thought this was just a lazy way to add lots of baby books since a nursery is added, until I realized the protag's hobby this whole time has been art and they finally made it as a children's book illustrator.[/spoiler] Also there's an achievement for putting the toaster in the bath tub so do with that what you will. Overall loved it and no game has made me so overwhelmed yet so at peace at the same time <3

150059483.review:
Note: I realize here that I'm going against the grain, but I must adhere to principles and judge this mobile app by the same rigorous standards I hold all video games to.  Before hammering away at the "unhelpful" button, consider that this mobile app art installation is being sold on the same platform as actual games such a Counter-Strike 2, Mass Effect, The Witcher 3, Cyberpunk 2077 and hundreds of other dedicated PC games, with cutting edge graphics and gameplay.  Furthermore, the developers have acted unethically and insultingly towards PC gamers with the market positioning for this mobile app.  I cannot in good conscience recommend games (and game-like art installations) to PC gamers when they're from developers who behave in an unacceptable manner towards PC gamers.  

On with the standard review. 

Unpacking is a mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as if it was a real PC game (it's not)... it's a cash grab from greedy mobile devs.  This barely qualifies as a game, as all you do is put your finger on your iPhone screen to drag and drop various items out of boxes into a room.  It's worth mentioning this simple activity (which in itself is not a game loop, which is why this doesn't really qualify as a game) is backed by a narrative.  Each consecutive room that you move into reflects the aging of the protagonist (yourself), as your possessions move from whimsical childhood toys to the mature and sometimes somewhat depressing possessions of an adult. 

This creates a rich narrative, to which we must ask, why couldn't they have coupled this narrative with an actual interactive PC game with decent graphics, instead of a mobile app with lazy pixelcrap "art"?  Imagine where this could have gone if the developers applied the discipline of, well, modern video game development to it. 

From a technical perspective, as a mobile app, this doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

A choice was made to use obsolete, decades old retro pixel "art" as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget or talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result.

While there are options to change the resolution for the game, all this does is scale up the simplistic 2D art assets used to make the game, which makes little or no difference to the graphics quality.  Without any other substantial graphics tweaks, it's not possible for gamers to improve the lacklustre 2D visuals.

The controls can't be customised because the game has such a dumbed down, simplified interface that it's just iPhone screen tapping stuff.  The fact that the interface is this dumbed down might be seen as a problem in itself, however... this is a fairly shallow experience if you're the kind of gamer that likes to play games with deep, rich control schemes and interaction.  You'll get none of that here.

Because this is a mobile app, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the iPhones that the mobile app was designed for.  These are unfortunate handicaps and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was an afterthought for the iPhone developers who are to blame for this.  The mobile app is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for mobile phones forces upon a game.  Once more, mobile devs have made gaming worse for everyone.  I didn't spend thousands on building a gaming rig just so I could pretend it's an iPhone.

These technical defects push this mobile app below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to scam PC gamers. On Steam, this is an eye watering, insulting $20 USD, on app stores, it's $10 USD. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay a TWICE THE PRICE, 20 BUCKS FOR A MOBILE APP just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  This is unacceptable disrespect for PC gamers.  Because this is a mobile app, is priced to insult and gouge PC gamers, and because of the other defects, it's impossible to recommend.  That's right, charging some gamers twice as much as other gamers just because you don't like the platform they use and prefer they used mobile phones for gaming is unethical discrimination towards a specific group of gamers. 

I appreciate the game is AeStHeTiC, and I absolutely agree that it's "charming", but the entirety of the charm of the game can be captured by a youtube video.  It's very difficult to suggest I should tell gamers to pay TWICE AS MUCH on PC for a mobile app that might as well be a 10 minute video on TikTok.  Instead we should be asking why the developers wasted their talent on making a mobile app when they could have created a truly 3D interactive experience on par with games like Life is Strange and The Last of Us.  Instead, they went the pixelcrap mobile app route.

$20 will get you a lot more high quality gameplay.  If you really, really want to play this, buy it on the app stores where it costs half as much.  You all have phones, don't you?

Unfolding the story along the way was very satisfying, and I found myself feeling quite happy for the main character in the end -- it's weird how simply unpacking her belongings tells so much about her life and what has happened.
Overall, this game is a fun concept and pretty well done, as I didn't find myself confused or wanting in the end (aside from maybe another stranger's story to unpack in the future, perhaps). 150000371.review:
This is a very cute game with lovely little touches that really make the story come alive. I'd say you could probably finish it will all achievements in around 4 hours so bear that in mind when thinking about what you'd pay for that experience.

You follow a girl from childhood (1997) to adulthood (2018) across 8 different scenes where you unpack boxes, aside from one scene the rooms you need to unpack increase as you progress the game. It's such a throwback to see all of the old tech you unpack at the start which I remember from my childhood which then upgrades as the years go on. There are also really sweet bits that you notice as you go such as she gains a new souvenir whenever she goes abroad, her childhood piggy teddy starts showing its age and she ends up patching it up, and she collects little chicken figurines. Sentimentally you see the girl fall in and out of love and mature as the years go on. There were lots of bits I related to like moving into her college apartment with roommates and moving into her first shabby place. 

Gameplay wise it's pretty self explanatory, really well made and I didn't come across any bugs. It's point and click and very low stakes. The hardest part was figuring out where some items should go if they were packed in the wrong room, but wrong items are highlighted in red and you can play trial and error to figure it out. Hugely enjoyed but wouldn't pay more than a few pounds for it as it's so short and not incredibly replayable.

There is a little plot to the game but it is not very essential in enjoying the game mechanics as is.

149939078.review:
This review is specially made for those who like to get all the achievements in games (minor spoilers ahead).

[b]Description:[/b]
Unpacking is a short and casual point and click puzzle game where you have to unpack items from boxes and place them in the right place. There are many different types of items that belong to specific parts of the house and specific compartments within that room.

There isn’t a written or narrated story, but the title of each level, the contents of the house and the rooms that are available tell a story by themselves and you can see the progress of the character’s life. This life story seems very personal and auto-biographical and it might be even inspired by one of the developer’s life events.

The graphics are pixel art based, but are very detailed with lots of interesting details and some interactable objects like game consoles and you’ll find quite a few different ones from the 90’s and early 00’s. The soundtrack is nostalgic and relaxing and the sounds of each type of object are realistic and distinct and that is a nice touch. 

The gameplay itself is simple and easy. The correct placing of the objects is easy to figure out with common sense but a few placements seem a bit arbitrary, but, in any case, with just a few tries you’ll figure out the right place for the item. In most levels you also won’t run out of space easily so you don’t have to be very meticulous with the object placement.
   

[b]Achievements:[/b]  
[b]How many:[/b] 25 Achievements.
[b]How much time:[/b] 3 hours, playing at a slow pace and without a guide.
[b]Game difficulty:[/b] Very Easy, it’s easy to find the right placement for the items.
[b]Achievements’ Difficulty:[/b] Easy. Some of the achievements are for completing the levels and the rest are for doing specific things in some of the levels. You can find hints for these within the sticker album inside the same or by checking the global achievement’s page. When I completed the game, I just went back to the previous levels and figured out the missing achievements in a few minutes, so it won’t be too hard, but there’s also a very good guide available. 


[b]Overall opinion:[/b]  
Unpacking is a cute and relaxing P&C puzzle game that is to play in short sessions. It has a very relaxing and nostalgic ambiance and the levels and achievements are easy to complete.


[b]Join and follow my group [u][url=store.steampowered.com/curator/42556190-Ribbon-Hunters/] Ribbon Hunters[/url][/u] for more suggestions and reviews of easy indie games to get all the achievements.[/b]

149919617.review:
This game is currently in the Humble Choice for November  2023, and this is part of my coverage of the bundle. If you are interested in the game and it's before December 5th, 2023, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

Storytelling by finding a place for everything. 

Unpacking is mostly about a unique narrative told through the act of unpacking boxes. The player has to open boxes and move items around to figure out where everything goes. It can be as simple as finding an underwear drawer and throwing all the panties in it. But it also can be anything from finding a good place for a clock radio or a diary. 

The problem is there’s not a lot of puzzle.  When the game is confusing and players can’t figure out what’s wrong with their choice, the game just kind of waits until players figure it out, and that’s just frustrating.  The player sometimes doesn’t even know what an object is, which makes finding a place for it clicking around, rather than storytelling. 

Before someone tells me, I know there’s intentionally no text, but without that text, it often feels like the storytelling can be accidental. I’m avoiding spoilers, but when something has to go under the bed, players of the game will know what I am talking about,  it feels more like a problem with the design of the apartment than a point in the narrative because no direct rule is being explained to the player, instead, it’s where the game will allow you to place something. This isn’t a horrible negative, but it’s something that always bothers me with the praise the game gets for that moment. 

Pick this up if you want a story told uniquely. Not necessarily a unique story, but this delivers an experience unlike anything else. That being said, it is only about 2 hours long, and it’s more of a game to be discussed than a game to challenge players. I’m torn on it but I did enjoy my first playthrough and this time was interesting enough.

If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my Youtube channel: https://youtu.be/NSoVlkgy0D0

149913858.review:
[b]"Unpacking" has a simple sole purpose. Unpack your things as you move from house to house. A really unique concept for nowadays action heavy, cinematic game industry. Gorgeous visuals, responsive controls, cheerful music and relaxing atmosphere offer a nice experience. Unfortunately the gameplay doesn't evolve at all as you play, while the story is pretty basic. Also, I'm not sure that I agree with its stereotypical core message which implies that happiness is having a bigger house, more things, more money and a baby.


Manometer: 6/10[/b]


The good
- Unique concept. Among all these games full of action, epic scenes and killing they decided to create a game for something simple, a routine, something that ordinary people do. They make unpacking interesting.
- Gorgeous minimalistic isometric visuals. Nice pixel graphics with great color palette and cool details. They have designed many different objects for you to unpack.
- Responsive, effective controls. Moving, rotating and placing objects happen instantly and accurately without weird snaps. Very satisfying.
- Fluid animations and. It's so pleasant to watch the cardboards disappearing. Also some objects change shape according to the position that you're placing them.
- Cool, calm music.
- Nice audio design. Sounds are simplistic but every object has different sound effect that corresponds to its material and the surface that you're placing it.
- Some extra features like saving videos and gifs after finishing your decoration.
- It has a cheerful atmosphere that may be relaxing for some.

The bad
- It's entertaining enough, but the gameplay doesn't evolve at all as you play. You do the same thing from the start till the end, just in different houses and with more objects.
- It tries to tell a story in an abstract way, but although you understand some major events it's actually pretty basic.
- I'm not sure that I agree with its core meaning. It essentially tells us that happiness is moving in bigger and bigger houses, having babies, making more money and having more and more things. It's too stereotypical.
- It may become a small nightmare, bringing bad memories to people that have moved out a lot during their lives or perfectionists that want everything to a specific place.
- Too small duration, only few houses.

149879045.review:
[h1] Overpriced but Relaxing [/h1]

Unpacking is a game that I finally got to play after hearing nothing but praise for it and for the most part, that praise has been warranted. It's a relaxing game where you unpack items as you move into new homes at various places in your life, from moving to college, to moving in with your boyfriend, to moving into a permanent house with your partner, there's a clear story to follow here without any cut scenes or dialogue. Is it anything too interesting or meaningful? Not really, it's very surface level but that's perfectly fine for this game and it adds meaning to doing what you're doing. Figuring out where everything goes is really only interesting the first time you encounter that room, for example the first time you get to unpack a bathroom, or an office, since that's the only time you need to actually figure out where stuff goes, after that it's just doing the same thing you've already done, and gets a bit repetitive, especially the wardrobes! Unpacking 20 pairs of underwear for the 5th time is just boring. Other than that though, the game is pretty solid. The graphics are simple yet effective, and the music is just fine. The biggest issue with this game is the price. It does absolutely nothing to warrant a $20 price tag. The absolute maximum I'd pay for this game is $8 and that's pushing it even I think. Either get this in some sort of bundle or when it's on a big sale, otherwise wait. It's a fun and relaxing way to spend an afternoon but not worth the hefty price tag. For more reviews, follow my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40795588/] curator page.

The story of a green first aid kit and its female sidekick.

It's a short game at only four hours--and a good portion of that was figuring out the last few achievements. I found it enjoyable though. Obviously, the game is about putting away someone's stuff, but thematically it's about digging through their life. At various points you get to see what got kept and what got left behind. Other reviews call it vague, but I feel it's tantalizing to never interact with the owner but just see their stuff.

The only thing I wish the game had was some way to ID items besides looking at them. Most are obvious, but a few are mysteries that would be solved by reading a label to see what they are. 

Still totally worth a buy whenever the price is worth 2-3 hours of entertainment.

After a stressful day, this game is the perfect thing to come back to while you simply unpack and organize clothes and objects and listen to the calming music. To the creators I nod my head to you because never in my life have I seen a more enjoyable game before. 149278334.review:
unpacking is fun. at this point i've played it through over 20 times. but its replayability depends on what type of gamer you are.

there are many ways to play this game. if you hate the red outlines screaming at you that you've put something in the wrong place, just turn on the free place option in settings. or, if you're bored, try out dark star mode, where you put everything in the wrong spot. you can also just try to find weird places to put things that are still considered correct, or go hunting for little glitches. maybe it's my autism, but this game keeps me entertained for hours on end.

the graphics are cute, the soundtrack is pretty good, the subtle story-telling is nice as well. and the sound design is incredible. there's a unique sound for pretty much everything depending on what surface you place it on. some items even make noise when you shake them. you can also turn on lamps, radios, computers, and game consoles. there are lots of little details. but the game is way too short. it's 3-4 hours of content on your first playthrough, and for the price, that's ridiculous.

although this is a great game, you should absolutely not pay $20 for this. wait for it to go on sale.

Unpacking is a short game. A really short game.

147943967.review:
First off, don't buy this game unless it's on sale. I am not convinced that there is enough content in the game to make it worth $20.

That out of the way, the content Unpacking DOES provide is FANTASTIC. It's a relaxing game about unpacking (who knew?) and I'm surprised I haven't played a game with this kind of concept before. It's the small details that sell it for me, like what items have been packed into what boxes, or what recurring items you keep as you move from place to place. I'm particularly impressed with how the game manages to invoke nostalgia, not just for myself thinking back on my own past, but nostalgia for the character you play as: her life, her belongings, and the way it all ties together as the years progress. It's a neat little story that does a great job showing you rather than telling. The music, sound design, and art style all fit the game perfectly.

You can finish the whole game in just a few hours and you probably won't feel a need to play the game twice. But if you're like me, you may end up returning to the game every so often. What can I say? It's a good game for me to de-stress. I suppose there IS merit in the whole "cleaning is therapeutic" thing...

Overall, a solid game worth experiencing, but unless they lower the price or add more content to the base game (what about a hard mode with even MORE things to unpack each level, making it much harder to find space for everything? or a custom room builder where you can place items from all of the different levels? even just one or two bonus levels?), I don't recommend paying full price for this.

147280215.review: This is such a cute game and very relaxing, too. It's also very heartwarming in a way. Despite the fact that there are no characters to interact with or a clear story to follow, players engage in unpacking boxes. [i] That's it? Unpacking boxes? [/i] Someone uninterested in this kind of game would definitely see it as just that, but after playing through pretty much most of it, I see it as unpacking a life. If you take a look around your room right now, I'm sure you can find things, small or big, that make it distinctive. The same applies to this game. You start off with one room, a bedroom, and it is evident that you are unpacking boxes for a child. From this alone, I'm sure you could assume how the rest of the gameplay follows. Nevertheless, players are able to witness a life unfold before them and evident changes of this life, like moving in with another person. I definitely recommend this game— 8/10, minus two points because it is pretty repetitive, and I don't have the best attention span.

[h1]Unpacking[/h1]

Are you tired of parachuting into warzones and fighting your way through mountains of 
corpses? Does your stomach feel queasy after buying yet another loot-box that won’t fix your childhood trauma? Is boredom a familiar notion you’re having, browsing through the endless list of monster-fighting games on steam?  Is your life stressful?
 
Unpacking is a zenful game about growing up, finding peace and watching life unfold.
By being observant, you pick up changes in her life, things gone wrong, precious memories, places travelled and hints of what the future holds. Even though the game is about opening boxes and placing things where you feel they belong. It’s more about taking a break and observing the beauty of life.

146317869.review:
Honestly, I found this game more boring than relaxing, and somewhat chore-like. Unpacking and putting away a stranger's things is more enjoyable than you'd imagine, but after having played a few levels I can conclusively say that shoving mugs into a cupboard is not my definition of GOTY game play. You can play how you want to a certain extent, but it does make you follow the in-game rules. I was absolutely floored that Australian "people" just leave their dirty ass Vans on the carpeted floor in their bedroom closet but the game does not allow me to put it on a shoe rack like a proper civilized person.

Like most of the over reviews say, it is rather overpriced. It has an average playtime of 2-3 hours, with no replayability or extra game modes. For a 5 dollar game that's OK, but this game is 22 CAD and just shy of 14 on sale. A bit much, no? There are people who defend this, which I understand: yes, it is from an indie team, but are we not indie gamers who prefer bang for their buck? I see no sin in avoiding a game due to the price/content ratio. 

I'm not sure what everyone else is seeing in the "emotionally impactful story" of this game. It follows the same plot line as a life insurance ad, and is about as deep as one. This is coming from someone who's a part of the intended audience of this game btw. All together it was kind of an underwhelming experience tbh.

146279867.review: This game is exactly as how it's shown, a relaxing and chill game of organizing for someone moving into a new place at different stages in their life. It flows through big life changes and hints, some cute like an item or two from college or an old item from home when they're older. I liked it as a busy adult cause I could just drop it whenever I needed to in order to do errands without worrying. It's sweet and there is a lot of personality, but I don't see much replay in this - I beat the game and so far assume you can just create a new name/file but it goes through the same motions. If you save it you can fastplay watch how you organized the room before which could be fun. Now, I bought the game for $12, when it was 40% off. I would say to definitely wait for a decent sale and not buy it at $20. It's great fun, but it's quite short. I saw other reviewers who finished in less than 5 hours, some may have taken longer, and it took me about 7 hours. Again, it's great fun, but way too short and lack of replay to feel that $20 is fair. TLDR, great fun, but purchase only when on at least 40% sale.

You pay for pretty pixels.
It's not worth the money. 
Items can be stacked and separated but for some reason silverware can't.
You can't set the table like a proper human being; tablemat, coaster, glass, plate, and so on. 
The protagonist is a womanchild. I deduced she is an illustrator (kids' books) but this can become a problem if you are not fond of plushies. 
Clutter can be exasperating and anxiety-causing for some people such as I who despise hoarding sentimental items. I wish there was the option to send items to an out-of-home storage unit (no player choice). 
Why can't the ukulele be hung? For the love of...
Most importantly, WHY IS IT STATIC??! Why can't I interact with the windows? Pull up the blinds or fix the ones that are loose?
Why can't the cables be attached and hooked and plugged in?

0/5 do not recommend at all

There are some levels where you can't really find room to place things that you know are important to her, and that's done intentionally to make a point about what's going on in her life right now. You get foreshadowing at the beginning about her cultural identity - and her sexual orientation - that then plays out later as she's finding herself as an adult. She picks up new hobbies and drops others, only for that lost hobby to reappear at the end. And all of this is told through unpacking her stuff and putting it away. It's intensely nostalgic and highly enjoyable, and I really wish we had another protagonist to explore, a "Chapter 2" with a different story to go through.

145588344.review: After a respectable playtime of five hours, which in reflection felt like mere moments, I find myself compelled to articulate my assessments of "Unpacking". This artful presentation, more a simulated tableau vivant of modern human existence than a conventional video game, illustrates the quintessence of relocating and starting anew with remarkable eloquence. The subtle nuances by which the silent narrative progresses appear as a metaphor for the impermanent nature of human life. The puzzling gameplay is not just an intellectual pastime, but also a reflection of the individual's existential confrontation with space and matter. In short, "Unpacking" is not merely a game but a philosophical epic in pixels. A must for those seeking the deeper meanings in the mundane.

145582367.review:
Beautiful game with a gentle narrative; a meditation on growing up, moving out and moving on. 

Hyper-specific experience here, but I ended up playing this on Boxing Day with my mum in the co-pilot seat. While she started off telling me she couldn't understand the appeal of a game about unpacking things, she quickly got into the groove and we found ourselves busy arguing about where to keep the spare toilet paper. 
That gave way to discussion about where life has taken me since I moved out of home over a decade ago; each new house to unpack a recognisable step on my own journey. The devs really nailed the rental market experience - as a fellow Aussie I can tell you I have lived in every rental depicted in this game. It was a memorable way to spend a day with her and while perhaps not the intended playstyle it was the most meaningful experience I've had with a game in a while.

Highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a quiet meditation on life that can be finished in a single sitting (and if you can wrangle it, get your mum involved too).

A game about unpacking a person's belongings as they move into new places during new phases in their life--should be something fairly basic on the surface, but the creators of this game are masters at environmental storytelling. There is a clear story throughout the game as you see which items you keep, which items you stop seeing, and which items of your former roommates' slip into your new homes, along with where items are able to be placed to pass

All my friends and I have strong emotions for the protagonist and some of the people she lives with, and we never see these people aside from some small photos to put up in these homes. But something as little as what we can move to make room for ourselves says so much, and I can't praise the creators of this game enough for the story and emotion they were able to create from just telling us to unpack some boxes

144790838.review:
What would you keep and what would you leave behind?

Unpacking by Witch Beam is made by an indie developer based in Brisbane, Australia

The player follows an unknown girl's partial journey through life. It begins when she first leaves home and we are greeted with boxes in each room of a small apartment. The story is not narrated, but well told through the different lodgings and belongings we have to put away from boxes. It definitely gives the player emotional responses, even without words, as the journey unfolds. With each new abode, new items will be added, and some will be left behind.

In it's essence, it is a puzzle game. Most items have limited possibilities of where they can be placed. If an item is not placed in one of its correct possible spots, the player is alerted and the item is outlined in red.

It can sometimes be quite a task to find a place for an item in an already crowded placement area. Thankfully the player can put items on the floor (or some other positions) in order to rearrange and make space for the item in crowded spots.

Pros:
* A very well made game which made it a joy to play
* An emotional journey, zen like, without words
* Mid level saving allowing the play at your own pace
* Easily accessible by players of all skill levels 
* Lovely music and graphics
* Possible replay value to get achievements (25 in total) when not using a guide
* Trading Cards

Cons:
* A little on the pricey side for a roughly 4 hour game
* A lot of the achievements will require revealing achievement spoilers or using a guide

Final Thoughts:
Even with the high price tag, it proved to be a very enjoyable, worthwhile and memorable journey. The quality in all aspects of the game makes it shine and a joy to play. Definitely an easy recommendation.

Rating : 8/10 (would be more except it is a little short)

144617550.review:
TL;DR : This game is way too short to justify a $20 price-tag, but if you can grab it for $10 or less, you should.
I was really enjoying the game, then I got to the final cinematic and thought to myself, "Wait a second... that was it? Really?! that was all I got for $20?!" It was a nice experience but it was spoiled by the feeling that I just got ripped off. This game should probably be $10 or less. If the devs had plans to add more levels later (which they apparently don't), or if they allowed for the community to create custom levels, it would probably be worth its current asking price (although even if these things were added $15 would still probably be a fairer price). 
Also, I have to say, I think it's a little annoying that the devs teased "big announcements" that just ended up being ads for new merch or just announcing that the game is coming to another platform. It honestly feels like a slap in the face to see these announcements. The only critique I've seen of this game is that there aren't enough levels, yet the devs seem utterly reluctant to add new content. I personally enjoy indie games in large part due to the tendency of indie devs to actually pay attention to what the fans want, sadly it seems as though this is not the case when it comes to Unpacking.

Everyone was talking about this game so I was curious and got myself a copy. The graphic is very cute and the music is great. I get the charm and why people like this game so much, but I guess it's not for me, sadly.
Maybe because there is no concrete goals (which some people may appreciate, but not me), but then the game doesn't let you proceed if you place something in the "wrong place". And sometimes I don't even know what that stuff is and figuring out the "right place" for that particular item is really frustrating.
I don't like how you can't expect what is coming out from the boxes next, there is no indicator on what stuff is in which box, and the way the stuffs in the boxes are not organized in categories grates on my nerves (At least put all the books in one box and all the clothes in another box, for example. How the heck did I find one shoe in the bedroom and one in the kitchen?! At least put them together, please!). Some places (like the kitchen) still feel really cluttered even after I tried a lot of things, so I just gave up. I ended up getting agitated with thinning patience playing this game. If you like categorizing your stuff and play games with clear objectives like me, maybe this one isn't for you.

It's a really fun and relaxing game. There is a storyline that unfolds as years pass by and you realise this character had to face some challenges during certain times while placing stuff -  because there is a reason you can't put everything as you wish. But, the game also has a "constraint-free" option where you place everything to your liking, I'm glad they put that option.

Definitely a good buy on sale, and for how much I paid for it i think i got my money's worth.

But i have to think, if I paid MSRP (20 US dollars at time of writing) would i have felt as happy? and the answer is unfortunately no as of right now. It's a fun puzzle game, it's visually amazing, the story is subtle but intriguing.

But it is WAY too short for how much it costs. Right when you feel yourself start getting into it, the game is over. and there's not really a lot of replay value, other than trying to complete the sticker book.

I really wish i could give this a more positive review because it's clear that the devs poured a lot of care and love into this game, but it just doesn't have a lot to chew on. If you see it on sale, grab it. you'll have fun but don't get too attached to it.

Very short game, some would say it's not worth the full price. I got it as a gift so I'm not going to argue about it.

However, let me tell you that it's a very soothing game. If you're frustrated, angry, depressed, or whatever negative feeling one may harbour, please, play Unpacking. It's immersive, cute, the music is not annoying (as long as you have headphones) and it's satisfying.
The story-telling of this game is very refreshing. Do not see it as only moving items and getting them to the right place. Pay attention to details, remember what you unpacked from previous levels and you'll learn to know our character(s). Even though, not a single word is uttered (apart from the album's descriptions at the end of each level), you can learn a lot about their lives.

143825879.review:
unironically stressful as hell. there are lots of preplaced immovable items all around the rooms which kills the "create your living space" vibe. even worse a lot of the time they're placed completely chaotically and the untidiness makes me frustrated. some objects are way too blocky, like you can't put a plate under the handle of a saucepan because the game thinks the handle hitbox extends all the way down. a lot of items require you to put them on the absolute top shelves even though from the looks of it you'd have to be 190cm to reach them. 

and you aren't even free when it comes to where you can put what, the game will force you to retry different spaces until you "get it right" and refuse to advance the level. the result is things like the kitchen having an empty towel handle while the bathroom has three towels, like in the third level you can't even put a bin in the living room even though it's clear it needs one because there is literally trash on the floor. also the person whose stuff you are unpacking has so many useless tiny things which clutter up the desks and drawers making it even more of an headache.

if you want to play this game to soothe your desire for tidiness, don't buy this game. if you want untidiness and clutter for some reason but don't want to mess with your own living space, or like untidiness and clutter in general, buy it. i don't think it was unfair for me to assume the game would cater to those in the first group. bought for a relaxing experience while i'm stuck in the middle of nowhere with garbage internet, had the complete opposite effect

143477334.review:
I've had my eye on this game for some time since I love chillaxing puzzle games. However, I couldn't see this game being worth the full price so I waited for a sale. Luckily a great friend gifted it to me on the sale day and I was able to try it out.

Unpacking doesn't flat-out tell you its story, however, you can piece it together by the gameplay. It is obvious that we are following the story of a woman starting from the time she is a little girl. The game does a great job of telling you her story through the items you "unpack" at each stage. I found this way of storytelling really cool and immersive as you see the important phases of her life. When she was a kid, going off to college, moving in with roommates, etc. It's fun and intriguing to see the items that go along through each phase of her life and which ones you don't see anymore.

This game is a puzzle game at its core. Each stage starts you in a room with packing boxes. It's your job to take out all the items in arrange them in the room as best you can. Once you finish unpacking all the boxes, you'll have to go through a final check. Any objects that have a red highlight have to be moved to a particular spot so the level can be completed. For example, toilet paper is not going to go in the living room. In the beginning, you'll only have to unpack a room or two. In later stages, you'll be unpacking a whole house/ apartment. It gets trickier when the space becomes limited.

As far as gripes go, I think I only have one. The game is pretty short and the replay value is low. There are 8 stages and the only reason you'll want to replay this game is to complete the special challenges on each stage. 

Final verdict? If you want a chillaxing puzzle game, pick this up. However, I suggest grabbing it when it goes on sale for about 12 dollars. I don't feel it's worth 20. The music was relaxing, and the story was quite enjoyable, but I once again have to reiterate that it's quite short. Other than that, give it a try and unpack your life. Thanks for reading!

To describe this game in one word: relaxing. (Though admittedly I played through the game the first time around like a madman, hardly stopped playing until I completed it.) It took me around 3.5 hours or to complete. With that in mind, I would recommend waiting for a sale--I got it half off and it falls relatively into the "worth it" range, but I don't think it would be at full price. However, despite having finished the game, I am still playing it--I load it up to play a level every now and then when I want a calm, relaxing game to play when I'm either unwinding from work or about to get ready for bed. The soundtrack is also lovely, unobtrusive and I'd even say soothing--it kind of almost induced a feeling of nostalgia for me.

As far as gameplay goes, pretty simple--place items where your average human might put them, rotate them as needed. Much like any real living space, there are limits to space in certain areas--sometimes the difficulty of a level is figuring out "how do I stack these without them taking up ALL the shelf space?", though it's not difficult, in my opinion. It's also very satisfying when you DO get the items where they need to be.

Definitely would recommend this game (as long as you're purchasing on a sale), especially if you like calm, quiet games or if you like organizing.

143067414.review:
Unpacking offered me the perfect balance between creative freedom and a limiting ruleset. 

You start with a small children's bedroom and a small set of items to unpack from boxes. Once the package is "cleared", the game will indicate if everything is in a place the game considers acceptable. Misplaced items will appear with a blinking red border. You finish a level once the room is tidied up, and the next one unlocks.

You will progress through a variety of [b]levels[/b]. Sometimes they consist of multiple rooms or even stages of a house as we follow the life of our protagonist. The game is not challenging, but sometimes finding a small misplaced item can be tricky. There is a setting to turn off the placement check, allowing you to progress through the levels without adhering to the ruleset if you get stuck or feel stressed at any point.

In general, the game is very [b]accommodating[/b]. You can zoom in and out, increase icon size, change the highlight colour and use keyboard, mouse or controller inputs. There is no time pressure, and the game autosaves at any time.  

The [b]story[/b] is discovered by interpreting the items you unpack and the nature of the apartments you live in. The game takes place from 1997-2018. People who grew up in that time might find many familiar-looking items. Many, if not all, books and other media covers resemble iconic pieces of the time. There are also domestic and religious items that you might not be familiar with. 

The [b]time[/b] it takes to reach the credits depends significantly on your ambitions. Simply unpacking and finding a place that's allowed can be done in 3 hours. It took me 7 and then I started a second playthrough right away (there are 5 save slots) because I had a blast and learned that there is a hidden game mode with a different ruleset for item placement! It's also entertaining to try to complete the game according to a challenge you made up on your own. Like playing the floor is lava or trying to swap the purpose of rooms etc.

The [b]achievements[/b] for this game are visualized and and hinted at by stickersheets in the game. You earn specific stickers for placing or interacting with items in certain ways. 

Lastly there is a [b]photomode[/b] that I didn't make use of but I saw on the community page thst some people create little stories making use of the filters, frames and stickers that the game offers!

[hr][/hr]

I highly recommend the game to people
trying to be creative in a limiting ruleset. You can spend a lot of time here!
enjoying short experiences that don't mind the price (or get it on sale)
being a kid/teenager starting in 1997 looking for some nostalgia

If you are looking for action, a puzzle to think about, or a complex story, this game might not be for you.

142622940.review:
Unpacking is a cute little game in which you follow the protagonist of the game through different stages of their life starting in their kids bedroom and help them decorate their home through out these times. The game is divided in different chapters, named after the year in which the specific chapter takes place.

The game tells alot of its story visually, you get to know the protagonist through different visual clues which the game is giving you. For example that they like gaming or that they were doing cosplay at some point in their life. Those and many more little details make Unpscking so great in its visual story telling. 

The game does ALOT OF things right but there are a few smaller things that annoyed me personally ~ for example that you can only place some items in dpecific places/areas around the house. Or that even tho there is technically enough room, you can't place a smaller item next to other items. That mostly happened to me with pots or pans. 

But maybe the point that some items can only be in specific areas  around the house or room is also part of the visual narrative of the game, who knows? 

Overall I can wholeheartedly recommend the game to people who like cute, cozy and chill games or just people who want to play something relaxing after a long day. Due to its short playtime you could probably finish it in one sitting if you wanted to, but i'd personally recommend that you take your time with it.

142598332.review:
Unpacking is a very relaxing game about moving into a new home and figuring out how to best place your belongings. It not only encourages you to be creative, but it's also a fun puzzle, since you need to discover how to best use the space in order for everything to fit. The game also doesn't let you complete a level until all items are in places where it makes sense, so you can't just throw a roll of toilet paper on a table and call it a day; you need to organize everything properly, and in some levels it can actually get a bit challenging! It's nothing excruatingly hard, but rather just a fun little challenge to tackle.

The fun puzzle element, the relaxing soundtrack, the cute art style and even some indirect storytelling all work together pretty well to create a very unique and fun experience. It may be a bit short, but I don't think a game like this necessarily needs to be very long. It lasts long enough to stay interesting until the end, never getting stale.

I think the fact there's not enough replayability is what spoils the higher price tag, i'd give this a big recommend if this hits under 10$.

It's a decent game and a fun way to unwind for an afternoon, but i feel like it needs another layer of mechanics or item interaction. more items need their own interaction, like i feel the fact you cant open the sketchbooks or journals are a missed opportunity. maybe add branching level/item/difficulty progression by doing or not doing something, affecting the story, such as it is. change the level complete so you can do down path A or B. putting items in the childhood room affect what items you have in the college or later levels, make it affect difficulty. Items are also slightly abstract, it felt bad stacking books/games by size, especially when i know im mixing D&D books and textbooks together. a item tag that lists what the item held is would be a good was to let me embrace the zen of shuffling/sorting random items.

142520924.review:
I'm not a fan of games that hold your hand and this was great in that respect - you get to discover the story organically through stuff (literally) and you get a great sense of accomplishment from figuring everything out step by step instead of being flat out told what is happening. 

Unpacking and decorating is also incredibly relaxing, I've already played through the game twice so I could try to arrange objects in a different pattern. I'm an "organised chaos" person and the environment really made me feel at home, trying to cram spices and kitchen gadgets into a too small kitchen. 

The only gripe I have with the game is the fact that it will sometimes decide where you've placed an object is not okay (eg the french press too forward on the counter) which in my opinion takes away from how completely immersed you get while playing. All of a sudden I'm trying to figure out why the tampons can't sit on top of the toilet and getting frustrated because I have to rearrange everything to place them exactly where the game wants. 

Overall though I highly recommend this for a few hours of relaxing and wholesome fun!

142498786.review:
Here wishing I could give a Neutral review. 
I think the thing that hurts the most is the community that loves this game is begging for more, but it doesn't seem like the devs care. They keep doing these "BIG ANNOUNCEMENTS" getting everyone's hopes up about dlc, more content, or a next game, only to be let down with ANOTHER merch drop..... or this last one was about them coming to mobile..... They have finally come out and said there will be NO new content added to this game.... the story is all wrapped up...., but they could add a dlc about a totally different story character, they called the game "unpacking" why keep it to ones specific persons story(?), so i feel like its a cop-out. It's easier to make money off of plushies and t-shirts, then make more of the game.... 

Did I enjoy the game? Easy, Yes very much so! 
The story telling is great. You really get a feel who this person is and what they are going through. The art style is cute and cozy. The color palette is a great choice. The music is very chill and fitting. The sound design is satisfying. 

Do I think its worth the price? sadly no, there isnt much replay value to the normal gamer, and $20 is steep for so little content, so wait for a sale. :( Seriously when you look at other games made by small devs/teams feels like they give you more for your buck, and this game is seriously lacking.

I have a lot of hours in the game, due to me using it as a tool. when i feel overwhelmed i boot it up and it calms me. I feel in control and that helps me ground myself. I am not playing it for the normal reasons you play a game, which some would say would be the story, action, challenge, art, ect. I play it because while yes $20 is a lot, its still cheaper then therapy(lol). I think thats why it sucks so much there isnt more game to play... this game has helped me out alot overtime, so just knowing that theres someone out there missing out because of the price tag or the lack of content is just sad.....

142279711.review:
lesbian/lgbt coming of age story with a female aspiring artist protag, great game. childhood nostalgia.

when protag. moved into her 2010 space in the game... it angered me!!! having to place your shampoos in between their boyfriend's soulless black and white corporate aesthetic angered me. not having room for her art supplies as well shattered me, reminded me of my own experience trying to 'fit yourself' into your partner's life. there were obvious creative differences in these people from a psychological perspective; he didn't accommodate for her whatsoever :/ i noticed the subtle message of protag. obtaining more underwear during 2010... ew? in short, objectification with that detail. and devaluation as a person with no space to pursue passions. the fate of heteronormity.

i jumped with joy when protag. got her first girlfriend in 2015 and this was a realistic and healthy time frame of half a decade. in this time-frame she found herself again and readjusted her life to a new partner. these two were which they were obviously compatible creatively and i liked the merge of their jewish and chinese cultures. it reminds me of school... i need to stop oversharing... happiness is (usually) found in women (AND WITH BOUNDARIES!) , i am so glad that this game re-reminded me of this. it teaches you that it's okay to go at your own pace.

though, on the contrary, one conceptual flaw with this game is cost of living. this game is assumed to take place in australia because of lack of weather changes and the credits scene. this game was (edit: *probably*) made pre-covid and definitely embodies the affordability of pre-covid life, it might be more or less relatable to some :,)? 

anyways, it was great, i hope there's another similar title released like this in the future.
